subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
According to Yu├е Ju├е Sh┼Ф (УХіухЋТЏИ), {{och-l|тци}} is also the {{w|Baiyue|Yue}} word for "sea". Therefore, {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} proposes an {{der|zh|aav}} origin; compare {{cog|mkh-pro|*d(n)li╩ћ||large river, sea}} (whence {{cog|km|ръЉръЊрЪњръЏрЪЂ||large river}} and {{cog|kdt|thl├е╦љ||sea}}). Meanwhile, Schuessler associates similar {{w|Hmong languages|Hmong}} forms like {{cog|cqd|tl╠Цe||river}} (< {{cog|hmx-pro|*gle}}) to {{och-l|[[Т║ф]]}} "creek, rivulet, rill" instead.

In contrast, Ferlus ([https://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-01182596/file/Ferlus2009_Ethnonyms.pdf 2009]) reconstructs тци's Old Chinese pronunciation as [l╔е] and connects тци to {{cog|qfa-tak-pro|*k-ri:||Kra-Dai endonym}} (whence {{cog|th|Я╣ёЯИЌ||"Tai endonym"}} and {{cog|lic|Hlai||"Hlai endonym"}}). However, Ferlus concedes that such a derivation of тци from '''*k-ri:''' "remains speculative, [...] not as firmly established as for Hlai and Tai/Thai".
